additions.definition: The left/right political spectrum understood as fundamentally flawed - not just incomplete but actively misleading because it 'flattens' multiple dimensions (scale, authority, moral vision, tribe) onto a single axis
additions.builds_on: The Left/Right Line concept, adding the diagnosis that the map is 'broken' rather than just simplified
additions.purpose: Chapter title and central metaphor - moves from 'the line exists' to 'the line is broken and needs replacing'
additions.why_new: Chapter 2's central thesis. The Left/Right Line was introduced in Chapter 1 as what the book replaces; The Broken Line is the explicit diagnosis that it's unfixable

additions.description: The origin of 'left' and 'right' political terminology: in the French National Assembly (late 1780s), deputies who supported the king and old hierarchy sat to the presiding officer's right; those pushing for radical change sat to the left. 'Left' meant less power for old order, 'Right' meant protect old order.
additions.book_usage: Shows the left/right terminology was never about economic systems - Marx hadn't been born. It was about attitudes toward hierarchy and speed of change.
additions.first_mention: Chapter 2, Section 'How a Seating Chart Became a Spectrum'
additions.key_insight: Original meaning: 'Left' = less power for old order, more for new nation. 'Right' = protect old order. NOT about capitalism vs socialism.

additions.description: The post-WWII hardening of left/right into a global battlefield diagram: USA as 'free world' (democratic, capitalist, individualist) vs Soviet Union as 'socialist camp' (planned economy, state ownership, one-party rule). Both sides invested in telling stories that sharpened spectrum into binary.
additions.book_usage: Explains why modern audiences think of left/right as primarily about capitalism vs socialism - the Cold War 'carved it into stone' and made the line into 'a battlefield diagram for a global ideological war'
additions.first_mention: Chapter 2, Section 'Cold War: The Line Turns into a Front Line'
additions.key_insight: The Cold War weaponized the spectrum - anything 'socialist' could be nudged toward 'communism' via slippery slope arguments

additions.definition: The phenomenon where the left/right line packages unrelated positions into pre-sorted bundles. If 'on the right,' you're supposed to like markets, distrust taxes, support police, value tradition. If 'on the left,' you're supposed to like redistribution, distrust corporations, support protests, value change.
additions.purpose: Explains how the line turns concrete policy questions into team loyalty tests - 'the important thing became less what you were for and more whose side you were on'
additions.why_new: Named and analyzed in Chapter 2 as mechanism by which the broken line distorts political thinking
additions.first_mention: Chapter 2, Section 'When the Line Became a Scoreboard'
examples: Right bundle: markets + low taxes + police support + tradition + anti-socialism
Left bundle: redistribution + corporate distrust + protest support + social change + anti-capitalism

additions.definition: The subtle and dangerous thing the left/right line does: it compresses multiple distinct questions (scale, authority, moral vision, tribe) into a single 'Where are you on the spectrum?' question, hiding crucial differences
additions.builds_on: Dimensional reduction in data science, applied to political thinking
additions.purpose: Names the core failure mode of the left/right line - it's not just simplifying, it's collapsing orthogonal dimensions
additions.why_new: Central diagnostic concept introduced in Chapter 2
dimensions_flattened: Moral Vision: What are we protecting?

additions.definition: The four distinct questions that the left/right line wrongly compresses into one axis: (1) Scale - how big is the group?, (2) Authority - who decides and by what process?, (3) Moral Vision - what values are we protecting?, (4) Tribe - who counts as 'us'?
components: Scale: Family of 4 vs. Neighborhood vs. City vs. Nation of 300M vs. Global market
Authority: Monarch vs. Legislature vs. CEO vs. Market vs. Leaderless community
Moral Vision: Freedom vs. Equality vs. Order vs. Loyalty vs. Care vs. Sanctity
Tribe: Family vs. Class vs. Nation vs. Religion vs. Party vs. Online community
additions.purpose: Reveals why the left/right line fails - it treats orthogonal questions as if they were the same question
additions.why_new: Analytical framework introduced in Chapter 2 to diagnose the broken line

additions.definition: The transformation of economic systems (capitalism, socialism, communism, anarchy) from tools or arrangements into team jerseys or tribal identities that signal which side you're on
additions.builds_on: Sports team loyalty dynamics applied to political identity
additions.purpose: Captures how the left/right line converts policy tools into identity markers
additions.why_new: Introduced in Chapter 2 to explain ideological bundling
additions.first_mention: Chapter 2, opening section 'The Line in Your Head'
additions.key_quote: capitalism, socialism, communism, and anarchy aren't just tools or arrangements anymore. They're your team's jerseys or a diagnosis of everyone else

additions.definition: The distorted, hostile characterizations that each system receives when viewed through the left/right lens, replacing nuanced definitions with tribal attack lines
additions.purpose: Shows how the broken line corrupts understanding of each system
additions.why_new: Chapter 2 explicitly contrasts book definitions with caricature definitions
additions.first_mention: Chapter 2, 'The Line in Your Head' section
caricatures: Anarchy: 'animalistic survival of the fittest' instead of 'voluntary cooperation → self-adapting systems'
Capitalism: 'amassing wealth on backs of the weak' instead of 'individual innovation aligned to community needs'
Socialism: 'placation of guilt via systems of dependency' instead of 'commonwealth share via economies of scale'
Communism: 'we will eat the rich!' instead of 'selfless generosity to shared greater good'

additions.definition: The Chapter 2 phrasing that identifies each system as 'the natural logic of' its proper habitat: communism as natural logic of family, socialism as natural logic of public safety, capitalism as natural logic of society-wide markets, anarchy as natural logic of friendships and emergent networks
additions.purpose: Provides accessible phrasing for the habitat-system fit concept
additions.why_new: Explicit 'natural logic of' formulation appears in Chapter 2 closing
additions.first_mention: Chapter 2, Section 'Dropping the Line, Finding the Map'

chapter_themes: Origin story of the left/right line (French Revolution → Industrial Revolution → Cold War → Media)
The line is broken, not just incomplete
Flattening: multiple dimensions compressed into one axis
Real systems (like slug line) refuse to sit on the spectrum
The question is 'Where do systems belong?' not 'Where do you fall?'
